newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenyan 1995/96 coffee earnings seen down 25 pct.
newsitem.headline: Kenyan 1995/96 coffee earnings seen down 25 pct.

text.p: A strong local currency and decline in world prices will cut Kenya's coffee earnings this marketing year by 25 percent, traders said on Wednesday.

"Assuming that the Kenyan shilling remains at current rates until October 1996, total earnings for marketing year 1995/96 (October/September) are forecast to decline by nearly 25 percent," a senior trader told Reuters.
Coffee Board of Kenya figures showed 1994/95 coffee earnings of $282 million against $244 million in 1993/94 with coffee Kenya's third foreign exchange earner after tourism and tea.
Private industry experts predict a marginal rise in Kenya's coffee output in 1995/96 to 96,000 tonnes from 94,800 in 1994/95. The Coffee Board has forecast production at 100,000 tonnes.
"Our output targets are still in sight and the coffee bushes are doing well," said Board General Manager Aggrey Ole Murunga.

Kenya's coffee stocks reached 741,000 bags at the end of 1994/95 due to lower export volume and increased production and although exports in 1995/96 are forecast to rise, stocks will still rise to 772,000 bags.
"The Kenyan coffee industry is concerned that with the increased level of production, stocks may continue to rise in the short-term," an official from a leading coffee house said.

A senior Coffee Board official said the 25 percent drop in earnings was still "mere market speculation" but the correct picture would emerge when export auctions resumed on August 27 after a a two-week recess.
At Kenya's weekly export auctions in Nairobi coffee is weighed in 60 kg bags but sold in units of 50 kg.

In the first half of 1995/96, the average Kenyan auction price for a 50-kg bag was 6,409.06 shillings ($110 at March rates) compared with 8,679.49 shillings ($148.36) in the same period in 1994/95, coffee auction figures showed.
The Central Bank of Kenya posted the shilling at a commercial mean of 56.99 against the dollar on Wednesday.
In recent months, mainly estate farmers have urged the government to allow them the right to decide whether to sell at the auctions or by private treaty.
The Coffee Board has consistently rejected these appeals on the grounds that dismantling the auction system will make buyers lose confidence and dramatically lower prices.
The Coffee Board also maintains the system ensures quality coffee is available throughout the marketing year. With private sales, there will be no such assurance, senior board officials say.
A task force appointed by Agriculture Minister Simeon Nyachae to review the coffee industry in May reported that many buyers saw auctions as best suited for Kenya.

Nyachae's office has since commissioned an independent European Union-funded probe by audit and management firm Price Waterhouse on marketing and management in the sector. --Nairobi Newsroom ++254-2 330-261
